div.head: The Printer to the READER.
div.p: THis ≈ømall Tract, now above two yeares pa≈øt, was by mee printed for that worthy Knight the Authour thereof, with no intent to have it publi≈øhed: and being hitherto by mee ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed from reprinting here at home; I find it to be of late time printed in Scotland (contrary both to the Authours and my expectation) and Dedicated by another man to the Bi≈øhops and Clergy there, and ≈øo made more publique, being of it ≈øelfe private, then was fir≈øt intended: which (I ≈øuppo≈øe) had the Authour knowne, or once mi≈ødoubted the ≈øequel, in≈øtead of De non temerandis Eccle≈øiis, he would have ≈øtudied another Title, De non temerandis Scriptis alienis: that his writings might not be imprinted, when Benefices are made proper. Wherefore finding many ≈ølips in it from his Copie, I have (as well in the right of the Authour as of my ≈øelfe, (to whom the right of the ≈øole Printing belonged) cau≈øed it to be reprinted. And though at the time of the putting it to the Pre≈ø≈øe, I could not conferre with the Authour, he being then in the Country, yet hath it plea≈øed him ≈øince his coming home to adde ≈øomething more unto it, as his lea≈øure would permit him; which I have annexed to the end thereof. And thus have I attempted to make a private worke publique, le≈øt the faults of other men, ≈øhould unju≈øtly be ca≈øt upon him, that de≈øerved ≈øo well in ≈øo rare an Argument.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p: ALL the ve≈ø≈øels of the Kings Hou≈øe are not gold, or ≈øilver, or for u≈øes of Honour. Some be common ≈øtuffe, and for meane ≈øervices, yet profitable. Of the fir≈øt ≈øort, I am ≈øure this Tract is not. Whether of the other or no, I leave that to thy judgement. To deale plainely; my ≈øelfe have no great opinion of it; as finding mine owne imperfections, and writing it onely upon a private occa≈øion to a private freind, without curious ob≈øervation of matter or method. But having al≈øo written a greater worke (much of the ≈øame Argument) and intending to publi≈øh, or ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe it, as I ≈øee cau≈øe: I thought it not unfit (upon ≈øome encouragement) to ≈øend this forth (like a Pinne≈ø≈øe or Po≈øt of Advice) to make a di≈øcovery of the Coa≈øt, before I adventure my greater Ship. If I receive good adverti≈øement, I ≈øhall grow the bolder. How≈øoever, take this I pray thee, as it is: and let my zeale to the cau≈øe, excu≈øe me in medling with matters beyond my ≈øtrength.

div.head: A Letter ≈øhewing the occa≈øion of this Treati≈øe to the Wor≈øhipfull his mo≈øt loving unkle FR. SA. &c.
div.p: MY good Vncle, the ≈øpeeches that pa≈øt ca≈øually betweene us at our la≈øt parting, have runne often ≈øince in my minde; and ≈øo (perhaps) have they done in yours. You complained (as God would have it) that you were much cro≈øt in the building you were in hand with, upon a peice of gleabe of your Appropriate Par≈øonage at Congham. I an≈øwered, that I thought God was not plea≈øed with it, in≈øomuch as it tended to the defrauding of the Church, adding (among≈øt ≈øome other words) that I held it utterly unlawfull to keepe Appropriate Par≈øonages from the Church. &c.

But our talke proceeding, I perceived that as God had alwayes his portion in your heart, ≈øo in this, though it concerned your profit, you ≈øeemed tractable. It much rejoyced me, and therefore apprehending the occa≈øion, I will be hold to adde a continuance to that happy motion: (≈øo I tru≈øt, both you and I ≈øhall have cau≈øe to terme it) and be≈øides, to give you ≈øome tribute of the love and duty I long have ought you. Therefore (good Vncle) as your heart hath happily conceived the≈øe ble≈ø≈øed ≈øparkes, ≈øo in the name and ble≈øsing of God, cheri≈øh and enflame them. No doubt they are kindled from heaven, like the fire of the Altar, and are ≈øent unto you from God him≈øelfe, to be a light to you in your old daies (when your bodily eyes faile you) to guide your feete into the way of peace, that is, the way and place from whence they came. So alwaies I pray for you, and re≈øt,

closer.signed: Your loving and faithfull Nephew HENRY SPELMAN.

div.head: To the READER.
div.p: REader, this ≈ømall Treati≈øe was 30 yeares ≈øince written and publi≈øhed by my Father now decea≈øed; his intent was to di≈ø≈øwade a prophanation of Churches, and to per≈øwade a re≈øtitution of Tithes and impropriations to the Church; Wherein although he was not ≈øo happy as with Saint Peter at once to convert thou≈øands, yet was he not with him ≈øo in≈øucce≈ø≈øefull, as to fi≈øh all might and catch nothing; for ≈øome were per≈øwaded with what is written, nor can I ≈øay that others beleeved not; but rather thinke, that like the young man in the Go≈øpell, they went heavy away, becau≈øe they had too great po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions to re≈øtore.

Mi≈øcheifes are with more ea≈øe prevented then cured, men ≈øooner di≈ø≈øwaded from a reception, then per≈øwaded to a re≈øtitution. While therefore the great di≈ø≈øolution of Bi≈øhopricks and Deanaries is onely threatned not acted, I have cau≈øed a reimpre≈ø≈øion of this Tract, hopeing that (as at fir≈øt) it will finde ≈øome beleevers, and the rather becau≈øe written long ≈øince, by one, no Levite, him≈øelfe and children as his Ance≈øtours meere Lay-men, not having nor hopeing for any Eccle≈øia≈øticall preferrement, and therefore I am confident he tooke his motives ≈øolely from the dictates of religion and con≈øcience, him≈øelfe practi≈øing what he would per≈øwade thee. I know thy argument for retaining impropriations, Abbeys &c. is, the Law hath made them lay-fees, thou did≈øt legally buy them, and therefore maye≈øt lawfully keepe them.

I confe≈ø≈øe our Statutes of Di≈ø≈øolution have changed the cour≈øe of the fee, from a politicke ≈øucce≈ø≈øion to a naturall de≈øcent; and unhappily put a lay man in to the Prei≈øts place. But tell me if any Statute or humane Law doth or can take away the Dedication or the Con≈øecration of Abbeys, Mona≈øteries &c. di≈øcharge or annull the intere≈øt which God and his Church hath in them, and for which they were founded, as that ho≈øpitality, ≈øicke and feeble men may be maintained, Almes given, and other Charitable deedes be done,
and prayers be there ≈øaid, as is declared in the Statute. 35. Edw. 1.35: Edw: 1. ca: 1. or can any Statute divert, and di≈øpence with the many and heavy cur≈øes of the Church, upon the violators of Church liberties, to which the whole Kingdome hath not onely cried Amen, but by Act of Parliament hath enjoyned the Bi≈øhops to cur≈øe the violaters. If the≈øe be not removed, then remaine they ≈øtill dedicated, ≈øtill con≈øecrated to God; and then ≈øeeke and ≈øatisfie thy ≈øelfe, whether thou having the appropriation and Tithes but as the Abbot had them, and receiving the profit as the Abbot did, art not as the Abbot, tyed in Law and Con≈øcience or one of them to performe the duties: for that he was, appeares by the opinion of all Judges 18. Eliz: Plow. fol. 496. where it is ≈øaid by the Judges, that none is capable of an appropriation (for ≈øo the Law calls them) but onely bodies politicke not naturall, and the rea≈øon is becau≈øe he that hath the appropriation is to be perpetuall incumbent, which a naturall body that mu≈øt dy could not be. And that body politicke (to have the rectory, the glebe, and tithes) mu≈øt be Spirituall not Lay. For in that he is made Par≈øon (≈øaith the booke) he hath the cure of the ≈øoules of the pari≈øhioners, and therefore mu≈øt be Spirituall, for by the ≈øame rea≈øon that a patron cannot pre≈øent a Layman to his Church, by the ≈øame rea≈øon a Lay-man cannot be an Appropriator; For they are both Par≈øons of the Church, the pre≈øented Par≈øon for life, the Appropriator for ever. And therefore Plowden ≈øaith, that the Appropriator, be he Abbot or Prior &c. is as fully incumbent Par≈øon, as if he had beene pre≈øented, in≈øtituted and inducted: and as Par≈øon ≈øhall have his Actions, and that he that is duely made Par≈øon is thereby made po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor of the Par≈øonage for the ≈øpirituall Office,plow. fo. 500. attracts the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of the things belonging to the Office, and in that he is Par≈øon, he receives the Tithes not as granted to him, but as things annexed to the Office of a Par≈øon. And Tithes are frequently in our Common Law termed ≈øpirituall things becau≈øe annext to the ≈øpirituall Office. By the≈øe Bookes and re≈øolutions of the Judges it is cleare that the appropriatour was the incumbent Par≈øon, and had the cure of the ≈øoules of the Pari≈øhioners, Fol. 33, 35. and that upon the pre≈øentation of the appropriatour or upon the di≈ø≈øolution of the Abbey, the Church became voide, and pre≈øentative, as other Churches upon re≈øignation or death of the incumbent.

For appropriations (as thou now ≈øee≈øt) were but Par≈øonages
